articles.headline: Some at Fed See a Need to Do More for Housing
articles.snippet: Some members of the Federal Reserve suggested the bank may have to expand measures to help mortgage markets.
articles.abstract: Some members of the Federal Reserve suggested the bank may have to expand measures to help mortgage markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite extensive government intervention in the housing market, some policy makers at the Federal Reserve are worried that even more might need to be done.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Jack Healy

articles.headline: A Drug’s Second Act: Battling Jet Lag
articles.snippet: Nuvigil from Cephalon could become the first medicine specifically approved by the F.D.A. to combat jet lag.
articles.abstract: Nuvigil from Cephalon could become the first medicine specifically approved by the F.D.A. to combat jet lag.
articles.lead_paragraph: It seemed like the offer of a lifetime  earn $2,500 by flying to France aboard a private luxury jet.

articles.headline: Fighting Trend, China Is Luring Scientists Home
articles.snippet: China’s leaders are determined to reverse the drain of top talent that accompanied its opening to the outside world.
articles.abstract: China’s leaders are determined to reverse the drain of top talent that accompanied its opening to the outside world.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  Scientists in the United States were not overly surprised in 2008 when the prestigious Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Maryland awarded a $10 million research grant to a Princeton University molecular biologist, Shi Yigong.

articles.headline: In a Clash Over Cable, Consumers Lose
articles.snippet: As talks drag on, the Food Network and HGTV have gone dark for many cable customers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
articles.abstract: As talks drag on, the Food Network and HGTV have gone dark for many cable customers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chris Birckhead came home Tuesday night hoping that his TiVo had recorded “Chopped,” his favorite show on the Food Network. Instead, it had recorded a looped commercial from Cablevision, his cable provider, saying the network’s owner, Scripps, had taken his show away.

articles.headline: Suicide Bombing Puts a Rare Face on C.I.A.’s Work
articles.snippet: Since a bombing killed seven Americans at a C.I.A. base in Afghanistan, details of the lives of the victims have trickled out, providing a peek into the closed society of the spy agency.
articles.abstract: Since a bombing killed seven Americans at a C.I.A. base in Afghanistan, details of the lives of the victims have trickled out, providing a peek into the closed society of the spy agency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In the fall of 2001, as an anguished nation came to grips with the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, a slender, soft-spoken economics major named Elizabeth Hanson set out to write her senior thesis at Colby College in Maine. Her question was a timely one: How do the world’s three major faith traditions apply economic principles?
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Democrats Wary as Two Senators Decide to Retire
articles.snippet: The Democrats face a perilous environment that could hold major implications for this year’s midterm elections.
articles.abstract: The Democrats face a perilous environment that could hold major implications for this year’s midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The sudden decision by two senior Democratic senators to retire shook the party’s leaders on Wednesday and signaled that President Obama is facing a perilous political environment that could hold major implications for this year’s midterm elections and his own agenda.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Adam Nagourney

articles.headline: Abortion Foe Defies Party on Health Care Bill
articles.snippet: Representative Bart Stupak, a Democrat, has embraced the attention — and wrath — his amendment has stirred.
articles.abstract: Representative Bart Stupak, a Democrat, has embraced the attention — and wrath — his amendment has stirred.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENOMINEE, Mich.  Representative Bart Stupak often endures things others find unbearable. He crisscrosses a Congressional district so vast that some constituents live eight hours apart and so cold that the beer at his beloved football games sometimes freezes. Years ago, as a state trooper, he blew out his knee chasing a suspect, and he has since had so many operations that he now returns to work the same day, toting crutches and ice.

articles.headline: A Public Company Defends Staying Silent About a Legal Snarl
articles.snippet: For years, Fidelity National Financial did not tell investors about lawsuits accusing two units and several employees of playing a role in a mortgage fraud scheme.
articles.abstract: For years, Fidelity National Financial did not tell investors about lawsuits accusing two units and several employees of playing a role in a mortgage fraud scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Fidelity National Financial, the nation’s largest title insurance company, did not tell investors about dozens of lawsuits accusing two units and several employees of playing a role in an elaborate mortgage fraud scheme in San Diego.

articles.headline: Despite Risks, Internet Creeps Onto Car Dashboards
articles.snippet: Even as concerns rise about technology distractions for drivers, automakers are rapidly bringing PC features to the dashboard.
articles.abstract: Even as concerns rise about technology distractions for drivers, automakers are rapidly bringing PC features to the dashboard.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS  To the dismay of safety advocates already worried about driver distraction, automakers and high-tech companies have found a new place to put sophisticated Internet-connected computers: the front seat.
articles.byline: By Ashlee Vance and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: Retailers See Holiday Sales Rebound From 2008
articles.snippet: Retailing chains on Thursday confirmed that they had a better Christmas in 2009 than the previous year, which was the worst holiday season in decades.
articles.abstract: Retailing chains on Thursday confirmed that they had a better Christmas in 2009 than the previous year, which was the worst holiday season in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the game of chicken between American retailers and consumers this holiday season, the retailers won.
